awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Quantifying timescales of groundwater recharge and discharge in seasonally snow-covered headwater catchments
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the largest challenges in efficient and equitable water resource management in the western US is the high spatial and temporal variability in streamflow. Although total winter snowfall is the primary driver of streamflow, the relationship between winter snow and river discharge is becoming ever more variable as temperatures warm and precipitation patterns change. This variability is highlighted by Spring runoff in the upper Colorado River Basin during 2020 and 2021, where annual snowfall was close to average, but annual streamflow was much lower than expected. Recent work has demonstrated that a major cause of this variability is groundwater storage that responds to climate over multiple years. This project will provide baseline data to determine how and why regional groundwater storage varies, ultimately allowing resource managers and water users to anticipate and plan for annual water supply months to years in advance, eliminating surprises due to having either too much, or more often too little water to meet demands.

This project will directly address the implicit assumptions of water balance closure on an annual time scale. The work builds on decades of hydrochemical research that demonstrates snowmelt-derived streamflow consists primarily of “old” water and that variability in this old water is significantly related to variability in runoff efficiency. Sample collection and analyses using state of the art age tracers (e.g. 3H, 3H/3He, SF6), water isotopes, and major ion chemistry during this project will begin to elucidate the mechanisms underlying these relationships and how they vary with landscape structure, underlying geology, and climate. The work focuses on extensively studied catchments in Utah as well as research catchments (CZCN, CZO, USFS, USDA ARS, USGS) throughout the western US. Ongoing partnerships with resources managers in Utah, Arizona, Colorado, and New Mexico will facilitate translation of knowledge gained into application.

This award is co-funded by the Hydrologic Sciences and Critical Zone programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Streamflow arising from seasonal snowmelt in headwater catchments of western North America is the primary water source for urban, agricultural, and natural ecosystems throughout the region. Climate change is altering precipitation form (rain vs snow), amount, and timing of streamflow in these catchments creating a pressing need for new models and understanding of streamflow generation. These ongoing changes related to a warming climate are superimposed on tremendous historical variability in precipitation and streamflow, a pattern exemplified by the five-fold variability in Colorado River discharge at Lee’s Ferry since 1906. Even during years with average precipitation and snowfall, runoff efficiency (the fraction of precipitation that contributes to streamflow) can vary by 40% or more. The last two years highlight this variability in the Colorado River Basin where streamflow was well below average even though annual precipitation and winter snowfall was near or slightly above average. Coming after years of drought, the lower than expected water supply contributed to the first ever shortage declared on the Colorado River.

 

Intellectual Merit: Our project directly addresses the often unstated assumption in water resource management that streamflow in any one year is the result of precipitation that fell that year. We address this assumption using the radioactive tracer tritium (half-life = 12.3 years) which is part of the water molecule and decays at a constant rate. Our results demonstrate that stream water during snowmelt may be as much as a decade old. Stated more simply, the water in mountain streams at any one time is largely composed of precipitation that fell in previous years. These findings fundamentally change current conceptual models of streamflow response to climate change.

 

Broader Impacts: The results of our work are being incorporated into multi-year models of water supply by the two largest water providers in Utah (SLCDPU and WBWCD) greatly reducing uncertainty in annual water supply to over 2 million Utahns. This is especially important as these providers attempt to make wise decisions regarding water diversions for agriculture and domestic use versus wetlands and the terminal Great Salt Lake.  The work also has spurred collaborative research with atmospheric scientists who have identified a teleconnection between the north Atlantic Ocean and Pacific Ocean that controls precipitation variability in western US.

Modified by: Paul D Brooks
